results.title: Police [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Emmanuel Schlumberger, Gaumont-British Instructional, TF1 Films productions and Maurice Pialat
results.brief_description: In this detective flick directed by Maurice Pialat, Gerard Depardieu plays Mangin, an embittered police detective who against his better judgement, falls for a beautiful young Arab immigrant who is embroiled in charges of trafficking heroin. In his dealings with the criminal class Mangin oscillates between brutality and sympathy as he tries to untangle a complex web of crimes and personalities, lies and deceits in an arcane game in which he searches not so much for the truth, but rather for a result. The frenetic cinematography, intensified by the use of hand-held cameras, creates a sense of hard-boiled realism, as does the over-lapping dialogue and convoluted narrative threads. Mangin increasingly loses his way as his affair with the duplicitous Noira muddies his perception of the truth. Written by French director Catherine Breillat. Cast includes: Sophie Marceau, Richard Anconina, Pascale Rocard and Sandrine Bonnaire.

results.title: Police
results.creator_credit: Terence Macartney-Filgate, Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Candid eye”.
The misbehaving public performs for the camera in a half-hour miscellany of misdeeds. In a behind-the-scenes look at the hour-by-hour operation of a large metropolitan police force, this film presents a fair sampling of what keeps Toronto’s police officers busy

results.title: Poles apart
results.creator_credit: Rymer Bayly Watson, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Judy Rymer, Robert Dein and Paul Warren
results.brief_description: Gough Whitlam’s time in government symbolises the monumental shift in Australia from a country that was culturally bereft to one that blossomed, distancing itself from England for the first time to discover it’s cultural independence. Whitlam’s time in government was also marked by a number of initiatives of which some remain today like the establishing of the high court of Australia, reversal of conscription, changes to censorship laws, establishing the Australia Council, free tertiary education and a budget to purchase exemplary artworks for the country. Jackson Pollock’s ‘Blue Poles’ was the first and the most controversial of the purchased artworks. The symbolic purchase catapulted the sleepy Canberra onto the world stage declaring that Australia had arrived. This documentary with interviews, anecdotes and archival footage traces the history of the purchase of Blue Poles, but more significantly explores the profundity of it’s implications to Australian culture and society. Speakers include (the acerbic and witty) Gough Whitlam, (the youthful and articulate) James Mollison director of the NGA who purchased the work, Phillip Adams, Kirk Vernedoe (M.O.M.A.), Ben Heller (art dealer, N.Y.), Richard Feigan (art dealer, N.Y.), Lionel Bowen, Harry M. Millar, Frank Moorehouse, Lee Krasner, Frank Watters and Jack Mundey.

results.title: Pole vault
results.creator_credit: United World Films and Edmund Dorfmann
results.brief_description: Analyses the various skills required for pole vaulting. Shows running action, proper grip, selection of pole, Western and Eastern styles.

results.title: Pole to pole with Michael Palin
results.creator_credit: Clem Vallance, Prominent Television, Passepartout Productions, BBC and Roger Mills
results.brief_description: If the idea - a trek from the North to the South Pole travelling along the 30 degree East line of longitude - was simplicity itself, the actual journey proved to be quite the opposite. Using every conceivable mode of transport Michael Palin and his crew passed through 17 countries and filmed for five months. What you see is what they saw - warts, bedbugs and all.

results.title: Polar ecology: predators and prey
results.creator_credit: Mark McCarty and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Illustrates the interaction of animals in the Arctic and Antarctica regions. Documents principles of ecology governing predator-prey relationships, food chains, territories and breeding success of selected animal species.

results.title: Polar bear alert
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society, James Lipscomb and James Deckard
results.brief_description: Churchill, Manitoba is a small Canadian town known as the ‘polar bear capital of the world’. In autumn dozens of bears pass through on their annual migration. Meet the great white bears, the scientists who study them and the town that copes with their visits. Narrated by Jason Robards.

results.title: Poland: the will to be
results.creator_credit: Albert Waller and Emlen House Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Michener’s World”.
Documentary film, narrated by James Michener, which looks at the history of Poland since its “first birth”. Shows the gaining of independence after Versailles, the invasion by Germany in 1939 and the Russian intervention during the war. Finally concentrates on the social-political structure of modern Poland. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Poland: the land and the people
results.brief_description: A geographical and historical view of Poland and her people in 1961. Poland’s place in the world as a nation under communism. Life on a small farmily farm and in mining and industrial regions; Poland’s efforts at industrial diversification; the role of Poland in international trade.
